jacques-n commented on issue #3233: ARROW-4086: [Java] Add apis for summary of root allocator
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/3233#issuecomment-449081506
 
 
   A few thoughts:
   * Do we really need to expose root allocator? 
   * What do you think about have a summary object as opposed to a string? That way people can choose how to present it.
   * How do I know what the current allocator is at?
   * How do I ask for the summary from my current node up to level X? For example, if we have 5 levels of allocators and a rejection happens due to a limit at the 3rd level, it would be useful when that allocation fails to report the tree for 3..5. How would we do that?
   

----------------------------------------------------------------

pravindra commented on issue #3233: ARROW-4086: [Java] Add apis for summary of root allocator
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/3233#issuecomment-449207703
 
 
   > A few thoughts:
   > 
   > * Do we really need to expose root allocator?
   > * What do you think about have a summary object as opposed to a string? That way people can choose how to present it.
   > * How do I know what the current allocator is at?
   > * How do I ask for the summary from my current node up to level X? For example, if we have 5 levels of allocators and a rejection happens due to a limit at the 3rd level, it would be useful when that allocation fails to report the tree for 3..5. How would we do that?
   
   you are right, my fix doesn't address this. Instead, I can add APIs for 
   1. getParentAllocator()
   2. getChildAllocators() -> may return null if DEBUG is false
   
   It will be easy to build code outside the allocator for multiple scenarios including -
   a. walk upto root, and dump summary for N levels below
   b. walk upto first ascendant who is over-limit, and dump summary for N levels below
   c. walk upto first ascendant who is over-limit, and dump summary for all levels from that ascendant to the current allocator.
   
   Does that look reasonable ?

----------------------------------------------------------------

pravindra edited a comment on issue #3233: ARROW-4086: [Java] Add apis for summary of root allocator
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/3233#issuecomment-449207703
 
 
   > A few thoughts:
   > 
   > * Do we really need to expose root allocator?
   > * What do you think about have a summary object as opposed to a string? That way people can choose how to present it.
   > * How do I know what the current allocator is at?
   > * How do I ask for the summary from my current node up to level X? For example, if we have 5 levels of allocators and a rejection happens due to a limit at the 3rd level, it would be useful when that allocation fails to report the tree for 3..5. How would we do that?
   
   you are right, my fix doesn't address this. Instead, I can add APIs for 
   1. getParentAllocator()
   2. getChildAllocators()
   
   @jacques-n - is it reasonable to track the list of childAllocators in non-debug code too ? It seems wasteful to have another alternate mechanism to build this tree.
   
   It will be easy to build code outside the allocator for multiple scenarios including -
   a. walk upto root, and dump summary for N levels below
   b. walk upto first ascendant who is over-limit, and dump summary for N levels below
   c. walk upto first ascendant who is over-limit, and dump summary for all levels from that ascendant to the current allocator.
   
   Does that look ok ?

fields.description:
On allocation failures, it's useful to know where the memory is being used in the tree of allocators (for debugging). One way to do this would be by adding APIs to :
 # get root allocator from a given allocator
 # get summary of usage/limit from an allocator upto N levels (N is an input arg)
fields.summary: [Java] Add apis to debug alloc failures
